title: Markers of Alzheimers Disease and Cognitive Outcomes After Perioperative Care
description_brief: This study will examine the hypothesis that changes in the cognition (i.e. thinking and memory) after anesthesia and surgery are correlated with changes in markers of Alzheimers Disease in the fluid around the brain and spinal cord (i.e. cerebrospinal fluid, or CSF), and/or changes in brain connectivity. The investigators will also examine whether different types of anesthesia have different effects on these CSF markers of Alzheimers disease, or different effects on thinking and memory after anesthesia and surgery, or differential effects on the correlation between cognitive changes and CSF marker changes.

outcomeMeasures.title: Correlation Between Perioperative Change in Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Markers of Alzheimers Disease and Perioperative Cognitive Change
outcomeMeasures.description: Spearman correlation was used here as the CSF markers follow a skewed distribution. Spearman correlation describes the strength of the monotonic relationship between two measures and is bounded between -1 and 1. Negative values indicate an inverse relationship while positive values mean that the variables move in tandem.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Analysis for the primary and secondary outcome 6 use the combination of both randomized treatment groups. The treatment groups are separated and compared in secondary analysis of outcomes 3-5, and the control group is only used in tertiary analyses. To be included in the outcome analysis patients must have returned for six-week follow-up visit.

outcomeMeasures.title: Continuous Cognitive Index Score Change Difference Between Anesthetic Agent Groups
outcomeMeasures.description: To characterize cognitive function over time, while minimizing potential redundancy in the cognitive measures, a factor analysis was performed on the 10 cognitive test scores from baseline. To quantify overall cognitive function, a baseline cognitive index was first calculated as the mean of the preoperative domain scores. The cognitive index score has a mean of zero, thus any positive score is above the mean, any negative score is below the mean. A continuous change score was then calculated by subtracting the baseline from the 6-week cognitive index. A negative change score indicating decline and a positive score indicating improvement. The resulting outcome measure is unbounded with a standard deviation of 0.31 in the full surgical cohort.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Analysis for the primary and secondary outcome 6 use the combination of both randomized treatment groups. The treatment groups are separated and compared in secondary analysis of outcomes 3-5, and the control group is only used in tertiary analyses. To be included in the outcome analysis patients must have returned for six-week follow-up visit.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial (MADCO-PC) examines whether cognitive changes after anesthesia/surgery correlate with changes in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) markers of Alzheimer’s disease and whether different anesthetic types have different effects on those CSF markers or cognition. This is an observational/interventional perioperative biomarker and cognition study, not a trial of an Alzheimer’s-targeting therapeutic. citeturn0search1turn0search6

Act (extracted details): Interventions listed are total intravenous anesthesia with propofol and general (inhaled) anesthesia with isoflurane. No monoclonal antibody, vaccine, or small-molecule drug intended to target Alzheimer pathology (amyloid/tau) is being tested as a disease-modifying agent in this study. The publications from the MADCO-PC program report CSF Aβ/tau measurements and cognitive outcomes around surgery and compare isoflurane vs propofol. citeturn0search1turn0search4turn0search2

Reflect: Given the intervention types (standard anesthetics) and the study aims (measure CSF AD biomarkers and perioperative cognition; compare anesthetic effects), this does not fit 'disease-targeted biologic', 'disease-targeted small molecule', 'cognitive enhancer', or 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement'. It is a biomarker/cognitive outcome study relating to anesthesia effects, so the correct classification is 'N/A'. Published results also show no significant differential effect of isoflurane vs propofol on CSF AD biomarkers or 6-week postoperative cognition, consistent with the interpretation that the trial is not testing an AD-targeted therapeutic. citeturn0search2turn0search3

Web search results used (key hits): 1) Trial record / intervention summary for 'Markers of Alzheimers Disease and Cognitive Outcomes After Perioperative Care' (NCT01993836) showing propofol vs isoflurane as interventions. citeturn0search1 2) MADCO-PC descriptions on trial listing sites (ClinicalTrialsGPS / CTV) summarizing aims and interventions. citeturn0search0turn0search6 3) Peer-reviewed results and related publications reporting perioperative CSF Aβ/tau and cognition (British Journal of Anaesthesia / Annals of Clinical and Translational Neurology), including a randomized comparison of isoflurane vs propofol with no significant differential effect on biomarkers or 6-week cognition. citeturn0search2turn0search4
